metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Assessing the Impact of a Rapidly Scaled Virtual Urgent Care in New York City During the COVID19 Pandemic Title: Assessing the Impact of a Rapidly Scaled Virtual Urgent Care in New York City During the COVID19 Pandemic Title: Assessing the Impact of a Rapidly Scaled Virtual Urgent Care in New York City 1 During the COVID19 Pandemic 2 3

body_text.text: A virtual urgent care was scaled to manage a volume of more than 800 patients a day across a 25 large catchment area during the pandemic surge. About half of patients would have otherwise 26 presented to an ED or urgent care in-person. Virtual urgent care is an option for appropriate 27 patients while minimizing in-person visits during the COVID-19 pandemic. In late 2019, a novel coronavirus disease , caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, first 33 emerged in Wuhan, China. 1 The COVID-19 pandemic has since rapidly and aggressively 34 spread across the world, and New York City has emerged as a major global epicenter. 2 The 35 spread of the virus has challenged healthcare delivery and hospital-based care. 3, 4 National 36 shortages in personal protective equipment further strained patient care delivery in emergency 37 departments (EDs) and hospitals. 5 EDs in pandemic hotspots experienced high acuity patient 38 loads and severe boarding as hospitals struggled to manage patient placement and flow. 6 39 Primary care offices also declined to see patients with upper respiratory symptoms in their office 40 spaces for fear of infecting other patients, contributing to unmet patient needs. 41 42 To combat virus transmission and slow spread, many states have extensively implemented 43 social distancing and stay-at-home orders. Telehealth and virtual care were promoted as 44 solutions to deliver medical care while allowing for social distancing, and to help decrease 45 patient load on EDs. 7-9 Virtual and telehealth visits have been previously studied and found to 46 be effective for a wide application of medical scenarios, including dermatology visits, wound 47 care, psychiatric care or consultation, and infectious disease practice. [10] [11] [12] [13] [14] Telehealth care for 48 urgent and acute visits has also been well described. 15-18 49 50 Our institution has operated a Virtual Urgent Care (VUC) since 2017, staffed by emergency 51 physicians to treat nonemergent acute complaints, such as urinary tract infections, dermatologic 52 complaints, or upper respiratory infections. During the COVID-19 pandemic surge in New York 53 City, to provide care to patients seeking urgent care and to avoid in-person visits to busy EDs, 54 the program was rapidly scaled to deliver urgent care services to hundreds of patients daily via 55 a telehealth platform. Patients register for an available time slot on the VUC website, and 56 interact with a provider via an audio-video interface integrated into a patient-facing electronic 57 health record application. This study seeks to describe patient presentations to VUC in the 58 setting of the COVID-19 pandemic in New York City; analyze patient demographics, including 59 geography; and consider the effect of a VUC option to decrease ED and in-person care 60 presentations. 61

This was a retrospective cohort study of all patients who presented to our virtual urgent care 65 over a one-month period from March 8th, 2020 to April 7 th , 2020. For volume trends, we also 66 collected the number of patients seen daily in the 2 weeks before the study period. We 67 performed a review of collected survey data on all patients seen by VUC in the study period, 68 and retrospectively reviewed patient records for additional data of interest defined at the study 69 with an urban academic tertiary care medical center, an urban community level one trauma 77 center, a suburban level one trauma center, and an urban free-standing ED, along with a 78 network of outpatient clinics and urgent care centers. The network typically sees 300,000 79 annual ED visits and approximately 20,000 annual urgent care visits across these sites. The 80 network's virtual urgent care typically sees about 6,000 annual visits (on average, 15-20 daily 81 visits) via an online video telehealth platform. The health system uses Epic for electronic health 82 record (EHR) software (Epic Systems, Wisconsin). All child and adult patients presenting to 83 virtual urgent care from March 8 th , 2020 to April 7 th , 2020 were included in the study. 84

The VUC platform is fully integrated into the Epic electronic health record platform and is 86 available as a custom augmented Epic MyChart application on mobile devices and computers; 87 the platform permits patients to sign up for a time slot up to 48 hours in advance (up to 30 88
minutes before an open time slot). Patients can thereby be seen from their homes (or anywhere 89 else they might be, so long as they have a mobile device or a computer and internet access). 90

The application instructs the patient to complete a pre-visit screener for medical history, 91 medications, allergies, their pharmacy, and the purpose of the visit. The patient then logs into 92 the application and is "roomed" in the video visit at the appointed time to meet with a provider. 93

Providers use Epic on their computer for health record review and documentation, and conduct 94 the video visit via the Epic mobile applications Canto (iPad) or Haiku (smartphone). Providers 95 could function from a home space, or from a provided department office on-site. 96 97 Data Collection and Outcomes 98 EHR data was queried from the Epic Systems Clarity database with the use of Oracle SQL 99 Developer (Oracle Corporation, California) and exported for data analysis. Retrospectively, we 100 extracted the following variables from the cohort records: patient age, gender, visit time and 101 date, visit diagnosis, ethnicity, address data, insurance status, return visit to VUC within one 102

week, ICD-10 diagnosis code, and referral to an ED. We also extracted time stamps for when 103 patients entered the video visit, when providers entered the video visit, and when providers left 104 the video visit. In addition, the total number of patients seen each day was collected, and we 105 further captured daily volume for a period of two weeks before the defined study period for 106 comparison. We also collected from our administrative data the number of active providers 107 seeing patients via virtual urgent care during the study period, and the number of new providers 108 onboarded. 109

A voluntary survey was administered to each patient at the conclusion of their VUC visit. The 110 survey asked a series of questions, including: "Would you have gone to an ED or urgent care 111 center in person today if VUC was not available?" followed by discrete answer choices (ED, 112 urgent care, primary care physician, or nowhere). Patients were also asked, "How satisfied were 113 you with the virtual urgent care medical care?", "Did your VUC visit meet your needs today?", 114 "Are you likely to use VUC again?", and, "Are you likely to recommend VUC to others?" with 115 answers on a 1-5 scale for each question. 116 117

We performed a descriptive analysis of the age, gender, race/ethnicity, insurance type of 119 patients presenting to the virtual urgent care during the study period. We also reported the top 120 20 diagnoses for these patients and reported results of the patient surveys. We plotted the daily 121 visit volume over the study period, in addition to the two weeks prior to the study period for 122 comparison. We also performed geographic analysis of the distribution of the virtual urgent care 123 visits by ZIP code. Survey results were collated and the results were analyzed to determine the 124 rate at which patients would have used in-person care options as defined above, and their 125 average satisfaction scores. During the one-month period included in the study, a total of 17,730 patients were seen via 140 virtual urgent care. Patient demographics and characteristics are presented in Table 1 . The 141 most frequent diagnosis during the study period was "advice given regarding COVID-19 virus 142 infection" -5,162 visits (29.76%) -followed by cough, upper respiratory infection, "suspected 143 COVID-19 infection," fever, and viral illness. The twenty most frequent visit diagnoses are 144 provided in Table 2 . Of all patients, 454 (2.56%) were referred for an in-person ED evaluation. 145 146 Daily volumes in virtual urgent care rapidly increased during the early portion of the study 147 period, and peaked at 869 completed daily visits by mid-March ( Figure 1 ). Geospatial analysis 148 demonstrated a wide catchment area of patients for VUC, both in the New York City 149 metropolitan area (Figure 2A ) and the wider tri-state area ( Figure 2B ). The median wait time to 150 be seen during the study period was 6 minutes (interquartile range 0-21 minutes). Median visit 151 duration during the study period was 8 minutes (interquartile range 5-11 minutes) (Figure 3) . 152 153 Previously, during "normal" operations, the virtual urgent care was staffed by a single 154 emergency physician at a time; typically, two physicians were scheduled for sequential 8-hour 155 shifts per calendar day (or a single 12-hour shift). In response to escalating volume and 156 expected high patient loads, available emergency medicine attendings across the United States 157 were asked to staff virtual urgent care whenever their schedule permitted, as "moonlighting". 158

Recruiting was primarily done from the existing or previous emergency medicine faculty, or 159 residency alumni of the institution. We expanded the VUC regular operating hours of 7a-11p on 160 weekdays and 7a-7p to weekends to a 24-hour model; physician assistants were also added to 161 the platform. Providers were on-boarded, trained via teleconference and a focused Epic 162 training, and then staffed VUC in an "on-demand" fashion. Our results also demonstrate that VUC was utilized by patients in a large geographic catchment 210 area both within and outside the New York City area. Previous studies of the geographic reach 211 of telecare have similarly demonstrated wide geographic patient intake, compared to in person 212 care. 31 These data -both geographic and total patient volume -suggest that the patient interest 213 in a telemedicine urgent care service is widespread in the setting of the COVID-19 pandemic. 214

Physicians and physician assistants can be rapidly introduced to a telemedicine urgent care 215 model under emergency circumstances. In summary, our findings suggest that during a 216 pandemic telehealth video visits can treat large numbers of patients, lessen unnecessary in 217 person visits, provide a high degree of patient satisfaction, and help achieve public health social 218 distancing/self-quarantine goals. 219 220

This study was subject to a number of limitations. First, we did not assess overall quality of care 222 delivered via telemedicine. While the survey respondents were generally satisfied with their 223 care, it is difficult to compare telemedicine care to traditional in-person urgent or ED care with 224 respect to classically applied quality measures. In addition, surveys were collected after the 225 VUC visit was completed. This might bias the data in a number of subtle ways. For example, a 226 patient who was reassured about their symptoms or managed expectantly might report they 227 would not have sought in-person care after the fact if they felt in hindsight it would not have 228 been helpful. Similarly, patients who felt their complaint was minor but then needed an 229 intervention or were prescribed a medication might respond differently after visit completion. 230 231 This study was specifically performed during a pandemic situation in New York City, and the 232 results may not be generalizable to telemedicine or virtual care experience outside those 233 conditions; patients may prioritize care from a distance during the study period given the 234 circumstances. Satisfaction data may be influenced by the optional nature of the study; patients 235 who were frustrated might have been more likely to complete the survey than satisfied patients, 236

for example, which may bias the survey data. Finally, while the survey data suggests that VUC 237 was able to divert patients from busy EDs or urgent care centers, limited survey responses and 238 other confounding variables limit our ability to conclusively demonstrate this effect. We did not 239 specifically examine any specified 24-hour outcomes or returns to VUC or ED in this work.

FIGREF1.text: time stamp data to assess wait times and visit durations. Wait time was defined as 128 the time between scheduled appointment time and the time the provider entered the video visit. 129 Visit duration time was defined as the time elapsed from provider entering the video visit, to 130 when the provider left the video visit. To exclude inaccurate time stamp data caused by 131 occasional technical issues and increase accuracy, duration times greater than two hours

FIGREF2.text: Liability coverage was provided by 163 the group's existing medical malpractice coverage; New York State provided additional liability 164 protections during the state of emergency. 19 A total of 251 physicians and physician assistants 165were ultimately onboarded and trained for VUC in late February and early March. As in-person 166 urgent care centers within the network closed in early March, those physicians were also moved 167 online to provide additional virtual urgent care coverage during the study period. At the peak of 168 the study period, a total of 62 providers were available to see at least some patients daily via the 169 VUC platform, for a total of 364 provider-hours in that 24-hour period (March 25 th ).170 171 2,668 of the 17,730 patients seen in the study period (15.05%) responded to the online survey 172 at the time of visit completion. A total of 2,033 (81.16%) reported that they would have sought 173 care in-person had the VUC option been unavailable -either in an ED (11.86%), urgent care 174 center (37.49%), or via their primary care provider (31.82%). 18.84% of survey respondents 175 reported that they would not have sought care elsewhere (Figure 4). Survey results for 176 satisfaction and likelihood to recommend VUC are presented in Figure 19 clinically may range in severity from asymptomatic cases, to mild upper respiratory 180 symptoms, to more severe lower pulmonary disease. The most frequent complaints are 181 nonspecific -fever, myalgias, fatigue, cough, and dyspnea; less common gastrointestinal 182 symptoms, congestion or sore throat, or loss of smell or taste may occur. 20,21 The Centers for 183 Disease Control and Prevention reported a hospitalization rate of about 12% during the month 184 of March amongst confirmed COVID-19 cases in the United States, 22 suggesting many patients 185 with suspected or confirmed, but relatively mild, disease can be managed at home with 186 supportive care and do not require hospitalization. 23 No specific therapy or antiviral currently 187 exists for outpatient management of COVID-19, 24 but isolation and self-quarantine remain a 188 mainstay of public health management to prevent viral transmission. Our results indicate that 189 the majority of patients seen during this period would have travelled to seek care in an ED, 190 urgent care center, or primary care office, had virtual urgent care video visit been unavailable to 191 them. These results are similar to previously published rates of alternative care destinations for 192 virtual acute care, in which 12% of patients indicated they would have presented to an ED and 193 33% would have presented to an urgent care center. 25 The overwhelming majority of patients 194 had symptoms concerning for potential COVID-19 infection (Table 2); a virtual urgent care video 195 visit allows for access to care while observing social distancing and quarantine provisions. 196 197 A number of studies have compared telemedicine based urgent care to in-person care. A 198 claims-based analysis of acute care telemedicine suggested that patients managed virtually had 199 a similar follow-up rate and lower rates of laboratory testing and imaging, with associated cost 200 savings. 15,26 During the current COVID-19 pandemic, with shelter in place ordinances access 201the nation, virtual on-demand care provides access to care but allows patients to remain in the 202 safety of their home. 9,11 Urgent care telemedicine visits have been estimated to result in short-203 term cost savings due to diversion of patients away from more expensive care settings.16,25  204    Overall, patient satisfaction results in our study indicated the majority of patients were both 205 satisfied and would use VUC again (Figure 5). Patients from other centers asked to assess their 206 experience with virtual evaluations in prior studies have similarly reported high rates of 207 satisfaction outside a pandemic situation.27-30  208   209

TABREF0.text: The study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of the [removed for blinding], Office 72 of Science and Research. A waiver of consent and authorization was granted for this study. 73Study Setting and Population 75[Removed for Blinding] is a large urban academic health network in the New York City area, 76

TABREF1.text: an emergency situation such as a viral pandemic. Physicians were rapidly onboarded, trained, 247 and deployed to see patients on the platform. A large percentage of patients seen via virtual 248 urgent care during the study period had viral URI symptoms and possible or probable COVID-249 19; the opportunity to counsel and quarantine patients who do not require hospital admission at 250 home has obvious public health implications to mitigate disease spread and minimize hospital 251 and ED crowding. Overall reported satisfaction was high. About 50% of patients indicated they 252 would have presented to a local emergency department or urgent care in person if not for VUC 253 availability, suggesting successful diversion of thousands of patients from crowded hospitals 254 What does this study attempt to show? 263 This study describes the rapid scaling of a telemedicine virtual urgent care to treat and evaluate 264 a large number of patient presentations in the setting of the COVID-19 pandemic in New York Tens of thousands of patients were evaluated and treated over the course of the study period 268 via a virtual urgent care platform; a variety of diagnoses from a wide geographic catchment area 269 were included. Survey data indicates many of these patients would have otherwise presented to 270 overcrowded in-person care settings. 271 4. How is patient care impacted? 272In the setting of social-distancing orders and pandemic conditions, telemedicine virtual urgent 273 care may be rapidly scaled to provide access to care for a variety of clinical presentations, 274 across large geographic areas, and may help divert appropriate patients from busy emergency
